how: First, when the theme lacks clear connections to the surrounding context or to everyday experience, audiences struggle to perceive its relevance and are less likely to stop. Second, public spaces are saturated with distractions and routine activities, making it easy for viewers who are typically mobile and busy to overlook the work unless it quickly establishes a sense of relevance.

First, engagement in public spacesis often fragmented and easily disrupted, so lengthy or complex contribution processes may discourage completion. Moreover, when questions involve privacy or sensitive topics, individuals may avoid to engage because of the fear of disclosure or embarrassment.

card_title: Absence of a sense of connection
how: First, when the issue presented is not framed as a collective experience, audiences may perceive it as “someone else’s story” rather than a shared concern, weakening empathy and connection. Moreover, if the physicalization does not function as a shared space for presence, dialogue, and co-existence, the public are unlikely to develop collective responsibility thus develops into sustained public action.
Designers emphasized that unless the data reflects the lived realities of the target audience, it is difficult to capture their attention.
Using examples or individual cases makes abstract data tangible by embedding it in personal stories.
Designers also trigger questioning or dialogue to prompt discussion and encourage individuals to place personal experiences into broader public conversations.
Some designers chose to utilize social ties, leveraging trust within existing networks, as peer invitations were often more persuasive than official ones.
Designers frequently simplify processes so that interaction can occur within fragmented schedules.
Designers also used guiding progressive engagement to ease audiences into complex topics.
Designers sometimes facilitate onboarding to help participants overcome hesitation or unfamiliarity with the physicalization.
Designers highlight the importance of using inclusive design to ensure accessibility for all participants, particularly those from linguistically and culturally diverse communities.
Playful or artistic framing helped transform intimidating or heavy topics into approachable experiences.
Designers incorporated social or competitive element, as friendly rivalry or collaboration could sustain audience engagement.
Rewards and recognition reinforced the sense of achievement.
Enhancing safety and durability, like preventing tangling and anti-slip flooring to accommodate large crowds is a basic requirement.
Designers selected warm or familiar materials to reduce distance.
Establishing human-scale comparison helped audiences relate abstract data to their own bodies or everyday scales.
Some projects sought to create take-away memory in order to let it become contested tokens of shared identity.
Protecting privacy and anonymity is essential to ensure that participants feel safe when engaging with sensitive or personal data.
Ensuring equality in representation helps reduce social pressure and promotes fairness by minimizing visible individual differences.
Avoiding bias and misrepresentation safeguards the credibility of data physicalization and helps maintain public trust.
